case_name: Indian Steel and Wire Products Ltd. v. State of Madras

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1968-1970 of 1966 by special leave from judgment and order dated July 16, 1962 of Madras High Court in Tax Cases Nos. 117,118 and 119 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1968-1970 of 1966. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 16, 1962 of the Madras High Court in Tax Cases Nos. 117,118 and 119 of 1959.

facts.text: Indian Steel and Wire Products Ltd. is the appellant in all appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Steel and Wire Products Ltd. a joint stock public limited companypany is the appellant in all these appeals.

facts.text: Appellant supplied steel products to various persons in Madras State during financial years 1953-54, 1954-55 and part of 1955-56 from April 1, 1955 to September 6, 1955 at instance of Controller.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the steel companytroller the appellant supplied certain steel products to various persons in the Madras State during the financial years 1953-54, 1954-55  and part of 1955-56  from April 1, 1955 to September 6, 1955 .

facts.text: State of Madras assessed appellant's turnovers relating to those transactions to sales tax under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madras assessed the turnovers of the appellant relating to those transactions to sales tax under the Madras Gen. Sales Tax Act, 1939  Madras Act 9 of 1939   to be hereinafter referred to as the Act , the law in force at that time.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to tax on best judgment basis for 1953-54 turnover Rs. 3129520/- tax Rs. 16298/4 annas.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has been assessed to tax on the basis of best judgment. The authorities under the Act have determined appellants turnover during the year 1953-54 at Rs. 3129520/- and levied a tax of Rs. 16298/4 annas.

facts.text: Appellant assessed for 1954-55 turnover Rs. 3759216/- tax Rs. 58737-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: During the financial year 1954-55, its turnover was determined at Rs. 3759216/- . and the assessment levied is Rs. 58737-12-0.

facts.text: Appellant assessed for broken period 1955-56 turnover Rs. 1453292/- tax Rs. 22707-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: For the broken period in the financial year 1955-56, the appellants turnover was determined at Rs. 1453292/- and the same was assessed to tax at Rs. 22707-12-0.

Even according to the appellant, its turnovers during 1953-54 was Rs. 2912533-14-0, in 1954-55, Rs. 3971493/7/- and in 1955-56, Rs. 1725400/5/- . Therefore, there is little room for companytroversy about its turnover in the relevant years.

facts.text: Appellant contests right of State of Madras to levy tax on turnovers claiming they are not sales.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is companytesting the right of the State of Madras to levy tax on the turnovers in question. According to the appellant, the turnovers in question companyld number have been companysidered as sales and companysequently they companyld number have been brought to tax under the Act.

facts.text: Deliveries made under compulsion of Iron Steel Control of Production and Distribution Order, 1941 issued under Defence of India Act 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant asserts that deliveries in question were made under companypulsion of law and there was numberagreement between the parties. They were made in pursuance of the orders of the Controller exercising powers under the Iron Steel  Control of Production and Distribution  Order, 1941  which will hereinafter be referred to as the order , which was issued under the Defence of India Act 1939.

facts.text: Controller determined persons to whom goods supplied, price, manner of transport, mode of payment.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that it was the companytroller who determined the persons to whom the goods were to be supplied, the price at which they were to be supplied, the manner in which they were. to be transported, and the mode in which the payment of the price was to be made.

facts.text: Iron and Steel Control Order issued on July 26, 1941, came into force August 1, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: During the World War IT iron and steel goods became scarce. Therefore it became necessary for the Government to companytrol the production and distribution of those goods. In order to do so, the  1  1959 S.C.R. 379. government issued the order on July 26, 1941, and the same came into force on August 1, 1941.

facts.text: K. Thiruvengadam Chetty and Co. wrote to Controller on December 20, 1952 for order of steel products.

anchor.surface_text: On December 20, 1952. Thiruvengadam Chetty and Co., wrote follows to the Controller From Name-K. Thiruvengadam Chetty and Company. Address-Iron Merchants and Tata Scob Dealers 93, Rasappa Chetty Street. Madras-3.

facts.text: Controller forwarded indent to appellant for delivery in period 1/53 or subsequently.

anchor.surface_text: The Controller forwarded that letter to the appellant with the following remarks - The above indent is forwarded to Indian Steel and Wire Products Limited, Tatanagar, for delivery in period 1/53 or subsequently in accordance with any general or special directions of the Iron and Steel Controller.

facts.text: Appellant issued Works Order RS MAD RM/15/53 dated 23rd February 1953 to Mill Superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: Works Order RS MAD RM/15/53 of 23rd February 1953. Delivery P.D.1/53. Ship to Saltcotaurs Book to self. Freight To pay. To The Mill Superintendent.

facts.text: Transactions involved mutual assent in several respects including time of supply, terms of business.

anchor.surface_text: From the material on record it is number possible to accept the companytention of Mr. S.R. Bannerjee, learned companynsel for the appellant that the dealings in question were companytrolled at every stage, leaving numberroom of companycensus.

facts.text: Court finds transactions are sales as elements of contract present including mutual assent.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, we agree with the High Court that the transactions before us are sales.

facts.text: Goods delivered in Madras State for consumption there as per Tribunal finding.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the goods in question were delivered in the State of Madras. The dispute centres round the question whether it is proved that they were delivered for companysumption in that State.

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal found goods delivered for consumption in Madras based on circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, the final fact finding authority, that the goods were delivered in the Madras State for companysumption in that State.

facts.text: High Court initially remanded to Tribunal but later accepted finding after no new evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Strangely enough, the High Court at the first instance thought that this finding was unsupported by evidence. Consequently it remanded the case back to the Tribunal for a fresh finding on that aspect after giving both the parties opportunity to adduce further evidence oral and documentary.

arguments.claim: Transactions not sales as per wide definition in Sec. 2(h) but limited by constitutional entry 54 meaning per Sale of Goods Act

anchor.surface_text: The principal question that falls for decision in these appeals. is whether the transactions with which we are concerned herein are sales. Sec. 2 h  of the Act defines sale thus ... But then the power of a State to tax sales is derived from Entry 54 of List II of the VII Schedule in the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Valid sale requires: 1. competent parties 2. mutual assent 3. transfer of property 4. price in money

anchor.surface_text: As laid down by this decision, to constitute a valid sale, there must be concurrence of the following elements viz.  1  parties competent to contract  2  mutual assent  3  a thing the absolute or general property in which is transferred from the seller to the buyer and  4  a price in money paid or promised.

arguments.claim: All four elements present in transactions; hence sales

anchor.surface_text: Therefore we have to see whether all these elements are found in the transactions before us. ... Hence, we agree with the High Court that the transactions before us are sales.

arguments.claim: Dealings not controlled at every stage; room for consensus

anchor.surface_text: From the material on record it is not possible to accept the contention of Mr. S.R. Bannerjee, learned counsel for the appellant that the dealings in question were controlled at every stage, leaving no room of consensus.

arguments.claim: Controller power under cl.4 and cl.5, not exclusively cl.10B; cl.10B for stocked goods only

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with him that the iron and steel products could not have been supplied to any person except in pursuance of an order made by the controller under cl. 10B. We think that supplies by producers can be made in pursuance of an order of the controller under cl.5.

arguments.claim: Mutual assent not completely excluded; freedom of contract limited but present

anchor.surface_text: It is true, in these circumstances, the doctrine of laisser faire can have only a limited application. ... So long as mutual assent is not completely excluded in any dealing, in law it is a contract.

New India Sugar Mills distinguishable: no mutual assent there unlike here

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly proceeded on the basis that the burden is certainly upon the State to establish facts upon which a subject can be taxed under a financial enactment. But it accepted the finding of the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal

arguments.claim: Tribunal findings not based on no evidence, not violation of natural justice, High Court not perverse

anchor.surface_text: The contentions of the appellant that the findings of the tribunal about the quantum of the turnover were not based on any evidence, or that those findings were arrived at in violation of the principles of natural justice or that the decision of the High Court is perverse, are wholly untenable contentions.

holdings.text: The transactions with which we are concerned herein are sales.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, we agree with the High Court that the transactions before us are sales.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied test from Gannon Dunkerley requiring competent parties, mutual assent, transfer of property, and monetary price; all elements present as parties negotiated terms like delivery time, payment, despite Controller fixing price and buyers.

holdings.text: There was mutual assent in several respects between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: Our finding is that there was mutual assent in several respects.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence from correspondence shows parties agreed on delivery periods, terms of business, payment modes, transport; Controller only fixed base price and buyers, leaving room for consensus.

holdings.text: Supplies by producers can be made in pursuance of an order of the Controller under cl.5.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses 4 and 5 by implication confer power on Controller to authorize; cl.10B limited to stocked goods acquired irregularly, inserted later in 1946; transactions involved manufacturing, not stock disposal.

holdings.text: The goods were delivered in the Madras State for consumption in that State.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted Tribunal's finding as reasonable inference from circumstances: controlled distribution scheme for local demand, buyers were local stockists/dealers, small quantities, govt. departments; burden on State met.

holdings.text: The findings of the tribunal about the quantum of the turnover were based on evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected appellant's contentions as untenable; no reasons advanced; turnovers admitted close to assessments.

holdings.text: The findings of the tribunal were not arrived at in violation of the principles of natural justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant's contentions wholly untenable; no supporting reasons.

holdings.text: The decision of the High Court is not perverse.
Kirkness v. John Hudson distinguishable as compulsory acquisition without mutual assent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts involved statutory compulsory taking without assent or price bargain, unlike here.

holdings.text: New India Sugar Mills distinguishable as no room for mutual assent there.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the present case are materially different from the facts of that case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In that case, Controller fully controlled dispatch, payment; here parties had freedom on several terms.

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley 1

anchor.surface_text: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley 1 . In that case, the question that fell for decision was whether the words sale of goods should be given their popular meaning or whether they should have the meaning attached to them under the Sale of Goods Act. This Court held that the expression sale of goods was, at the time when the Government of India Act, 1935 was enacted, a term of well recognised legal import in the general law relating to sale of goods and in the legislative practice relating to that topic and must be interpreted as having the same meaning as in the sale of Goods Act 1930 In the companyrse of the judgment, Venkatarama Aiyar, J,who ,spoke for the Court after examining the various decisions cited at the Bar, observed, as follows Thus, according to the law both of England and of India, in order to companystitute a sale it is necessary that there should be an agreement between the parties for the purpose of transferring title to goods which of companyrse pre-supposes capacity to companytract, that it must be supported by money companysideration and that as a result of the transaction property must actually pass in the goods.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v Gannon Dunkerley
precedents.cited_proposition: sale of goods has the meaning as in Sale of Goods Act: agreement between parties for transfer of title supported by money consideration with actual passing of property
precedents.cited_holding: to constitute a valid sale: parties competent to contract, mutual assent, transfer of property for price in money

precedents.citation: North Adjai Coal Company  P  Ltd. v. Commercial Tax Officer and others 1

anchor.surface_text: North Adjai Coal Company  P  Ltd. v. Commercial Tax Officer and others 1  and S. K. Roy v. Additional Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal 2 . On the facts of those cases, the Court came to the companyclusion that the transactions in question were- number sales. For the reasons already stated, we are unable to accept the companytention that the transactions with which we are companycerned in these cases are number sales.

precedents.case_name: North Adjai Coal Company P Ltd v Commercial Tax Officer

precedents.citation: S. K. Roy v. Additional Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal 2

anchor.surface_text: S. K. Roy v. Additional Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal 2 . On the facts of those cases, the Court came to the companyclusion that the transactions in question were- number sales. For the reasons already stated, we are unable to accept the companytention that the transactions with which we are companycerned in these cases are number sales. Out of the four elements mentioned earlier, three were admittedly established, namely, the parties were companypetent to companytract, the property in the goods was transferred from the seller to the buyer, and price in money was paid.

precedents.case_name: S K Roy v Additional Member Board of Revenue West Bengal

justification_sets.label: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 support

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already stated, we are unable to accept the contention that the transactions with which we are concerned in these cases are not sales. Out of the four elements mentioned earlier, three were admittedly established, namely, the parties were competent to contract, the property in the goods was transferred from the seller to the buyer, and price in money was paid. The only controversy was whether there was mutual assent. Our finding is that there was mutual assent in several respects. Hence, we agree with the High Court that the transactions before us are sales.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's contentions rejected; transactions held to be sales; goods delivered for consumption in Madras State; sales tax assessments upheld

anchor.surface_text: Hence, we agree with the High Court that the transactions before us are sales.

For the reasons already stated, we are unable to accept the contention that the transactions with which we are concerned in these cases are not sales. Out of the four elements mentioned earlier, three were admittedly established, namely, the parties were competent to contract, the property in the goods was transferred from the seller to the buyer, and price in money was paid. The only controversy was whether there was mutual assent. Our finding is that there was mutual assent in several respects. Hence, we agree with the High Court that the transactions before us are sales.
Hence, we agree with the High Court that the transactions before us are sales.
